item.title: This Popular Game Is Banning Players For 10 Years
item.content:encoded:

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Free-to-play game Delta Force isn't playing around when it comes to cheaters. Developer Team Jade has revealed that 10-year bans--yes, a full decade--have been handed out recently to over 1,000 players for violating rules of the tactical shooter. The preventative measures don't stop there, either.

On X, the official Delta Force account shared statistics on how the developer is dealing with cheaters. From March 14-20, the game's security team said that 1,446 players were banned, 694 devices blocked, and more than 4,000 people forced offline. The Delta Force website notes that cheating can consist of "the use of plug-ins, illegal software, inappropriate behaviour, malicious use of exploits or bugs, etc." The developer also mentions a zero-tolerance policy, which checks out considering over 7,000 decade bans were dished out for Season Genesis in January.

Last month, Delta Force got a Black Hawk Down campaign. This add-on is actually a remake of the 2003 game of the same name. It's inspired by the Hollywood movie based on a real event that occurred in 1993, with the game featuring the Battle of Mogadishu. Meanwhile, the Warfare mode offers up 32-vs.-32 online multiplayer in the tactical shooter.

Delta Force launched on PC in December and landed on Steam's top titles for that month, alongside Indiana Jones and the Great Circle. The free-to-play game has seemingly maintained a healthy player base as well, with SteamDB showing over 52,000 concurrent players for Delta Force at the time of publication.

The tactical shooter is scheduled to get a mobile release on April 21. Afterward, Delta Force is planned to arrive later this year on PlayStation and Xbox consoles.

item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows Update Makes Key Changes To Shrines Amid Cultural Sensitivity Discussion
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/assassins-creed-shadows-update-makes-key-changes-to-shrines-amid-cultural-sensitivity-discussion/1100-6530252/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

An update for Assassin's Creed Shadows on launch day makes a couple key changes to the game's shrines, preventing players from destroying certain items in them. The patch comes amid a discussion about cultural sensitivity in the 16th-century Japan game.

According to IGN, the update changes the game so that the monks inside of the shrines no longer bleed when attacked, while tables and racks throughout the game's temples and shrines are now indestructible. Bowls and drums can be broken, however, and tables can be moved and pushed.

Earlier this week, Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba responded to a question about Assassin's Creed Shadows and its shrines. He said, as translated by IGN, that "defacing a shrine is out of the question--it is an insult to the nation itself. Respecting the culture and religion of a country is fundamental, and we must make it clear that we will not simply accept acts that disregard them."

Hiroyuki Kada, a Japanese politician, said he fears that if people can vandalize a shrine in Assassin's Creed Shadows, it might "encourage similar behavior in real life."

"Shrine officials and local residents are also worried about this. Of course, freedom of expression must be respected, but acts that demean local cultures should be avoided," he said.

A viral video posted earlier this year showed a player running through a shrine and causing havoc. This was not an objective of any specific quest, but instead the player choosing to do this.

In July 2024, Ubisoft put out a statement in which it said Shadows is a work of fiction, and one that Ubisoft enlisted the help of external consultants, historians, and researchers as part of an effort to "inform our creative choices." Ubisoft also acknowledged that some of the game's promotional materials at the time "caused concern within the Japanese community," and for that, Ubisoft said, "We sincerely apologize."

Shadows is out now on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S, featuring the protagonists Naoe and Yasuke. For more, check out GameSpot's Assassin's Creed Shadows review and our guides hub to help you get started. You can also find out how the game looks and performs on PS5 Pro.

item.title: CoD: Warzone - Season 3 Promo Art Confirms OG Operators Are Returning
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cod-warzone-season-3-promo-art-confirms-og-operators-are-returning/1100-6530250/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty: Warzone is bringing back the OG Verdansk map with the launch of Season 3 on April 3, and now the new seasonal promo art for Warzone teases the return of fan-favorite operators from both Modern Warfare and Black Ops games.

The promo art for Season 3 pays homage to the original artwork from Warzone's launch in 2020. As seen below in the side-by-side comparison from CharlieIntel, classic Call of Duty operators stand atop a crashed helicopter in Verdansk, much like the original artwork.

Warzone recently celebrated its fifth anniversary with a nostalgic trailer, and this new promo art further confirms that Season 3 is looking to sell players on nostalgia.

Call of Duty's seasonal artwork usually features key characters and operator skins that players will find in the battle pass or shop bundles. Jason Hudson of the Black Ops series is featured front and center, so he'll likely be the main operator featured in Season 3's battle pass. Hudson was killed off in a flashback during Black Ops 2 that takes place prior to Black Ops 6, so this OG throwback season gives the developer a way of adding the popular character as a playable operator in Black Ops 6 and Warzone.

Other notable operators shown in the Season 3 artwork include OG skins for Ghost and Mace from Modern Warfare 2019. Frank Woods is likely getting a throwback skin as well. Frank has been wheelchair-bound since the events of Black Ops 2, but he's standing and looking much younger in Season 3's artwork, so this might be a Black Ops 1 variant skin.

For more on Call of Duty, make sure to check out all the rumors and announcements for Season 3 of Black Ops 6 and Warzone. The next Zombies map is called Shattered Veil, and Treyarch teases the story could revolve around Edward Richtofen.

item.title: Xenoblade Chronicles X: Definitive Edition's Hidden Mode Could Hint At Switch 2 Feature
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/xenoblade-chronicles-x-definitive-editions-hidden-mode-could-hint-at-switch-2-feature/1100-6530249/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Xenoblade Chronicles X: Definitive Edition has a hidden mode that could hint at how games will perform on Nintendo Switch 2.

According to modder MasaGratoR, Xenoblade Chronicles X: Definitive Edition has a hidden executable that enables 60fps mode. However, when the mode is turned on, it seems to cause some undetermined issues. As for how the game performs on Switch, its dynamic resolution range is 504p-720p in handheld mode and 760p-1080p while docked.

It's unknown why the game would have this hidden mode, but its speculated that it could unlock when being played on Nintendo Switch 2. There's a chance that the game could receive a patch that lets it take full advantage of the new hardware's capabilities. With the full extent of Switch 2's backwards-compatibility limitations still unknown, though, it's unclear whether this is actually the case.

Nintendo is airing a Direct on April 2 dedicated to Switch 2 so we'll see more information about the system then.

Xenoblade Chronicles X is the second entry in the Xenoblade series, which tells the story of humanity as it crash-lands on the planet Mira and tries to make it its new home while searching for remnants of a ship called the White Whale.

Xenoblade Chronicles X: Definitive Edition launches today, March 20, for Nintendo Switch. This version hosts a bevy of quality-of-life and gameplay changes that the Wii U original didn't have. In GameSpot's Xenoblade Chronicles X review, we said, "X is a grand adventure that satiates your appetite for exploration and combat in ways that few games ever do, but because getting started is half the battle, it‚Äôs an experience reserved for dedicated players who have the patience and energy to unearth its greatest treasures."

item.title: Digimon Is Getting Its Own Free-To-Play Mobile Card Game Following The Success Of Pokemon's
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/digimon-is-getting-its-own-free-to-play-mobile-card-game-following-the-success-of-pokemons/1100-6530247/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Bandai Namco has announced Digimon Alysion, a free-to-play mobile card game. While no release date has been revealed, there will be a closed beta at a later date. The game will also include microtransactions.

Not many details about the game were shown off, but Bandai Namco provided information about some of its characters, including who seems to be the protagonist, a black-haired girl named Kanata Honde. The girl with short white hair is named Futre and it seems like she wields some sort of special power, and another girl named Valner Dragnogh. There's also a Digimon named Gemmon, who is a fluffy white creature with gems encrusted into its body, and it looks like it'll be the protagonist's partner.

The Pokemon Company found big success with Pokemon TCG Pocket, which is an electronic version of its popular trading card game. It's become a huge hit since its release, surpassing 100 million downloads, so it's no surprise that Digimon would try to capture the same popularity given it has lived in Pokemon's shadow for so many years.

Bandai Namco is also working on a new Digimon Game called Digimon Story: Time Stranger, which is set to launch sometime this year for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S.
